bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Homer N. Calver, December 12, 1924

div1.p: [Carter] expresses his gratitude for being named a Fellow of the American Public Health Association.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Homer N. Calver, December 12, 1924
div1.opener:
/LC
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
December 12, 1924.
Dr. Homer N. Calver,
Executive Secretary,
American Public Health Association,
370 Seventh Avenue, New York City, N. Y.
My Dear Doctor Calver:
div1.p:
I wish to acknowledge with thanks your letter informing me
of my election as an Honorary Fellow of the American Public Health
Association and I can assure you that I highly appreciate the honor
thus conferred upon me.

I have not been a member of the American Public Health As-
sociation of late years because my work for the last 25 or 30 years
has been almost exclusively confined to the prevention of two dis-
eases, viz. malaria and yellow fever. These have formed so small a
part, generally no part, of the problems considered by the American
Public Health Association that I felt that I would only be drawn aside
from my special duties had I taken part in its general work. In my
own thus limited line I have been continuously engaged in public
health work.
Again assuring you of my appreciation, I remain
